title: Job Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who answered Job in Job Chapter 15?
questions.explanation: Job 15:1 states that Eliphaz the Temanite answered Job.

questions.question: According to Job 15:2, what does Eliphaz compare vain knowledge to?
questions.explanation: Job 15:2 compares vain knowledge to filling one's belly with the east wind.

questions.question: According to Job 15:4, what has Job cast off?
questions.explanation: Job 15:4 says Job casteth off fear and restrainest prayer before God.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz accuse Job's mouth of doing in Job 15:5?
questions.explanation: Job 15:5 states that Job's mouth uttereth iniquity and he chooseth the tongue of the crafty.

questions.question: True or False: In Job 15:7, Eliphaz asks if Job was made before the hills.
questions.explanation: Job 15:7 asks if Job was the first man born or made before the hills.

questions.question: According to Job 15:10, who are present with Eliphaz?
questions.explanation: Job 15:10 mentions grayheaded and very aged men are with Eliphaz, much elder than Job's father.

questions.question: According to Job 15:14, what does Eliphaz say about man’s righteousness?
options: Man is not clean or perfectly righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Man is not clean or perfectly righteous
questions.explanation: Job 15:14 states that man should not be clean or righteous as born of a woman.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say about the heavens in Job 15:15?
options: The heavens are not clean in God's sight
The heavens are made by man
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens are not clean in God's sight
questions.explanation: Job 15:15 says even the heavens are not clean in God's sight.

questions.question: According to Job 15:20, what is hidden to the oppressor?
questions.explanation: Job 15:20 states the number of years is hidden to the oppressor.

questions.question: True or False: Job 15:22 says the wicked man believes he will return out of darkness.
questions.explanation: Job 15:22 says the wicked man believeth not that he shall return out of darkness.

questions.question: According to Job 15:25, what does the wicked man stretch out his hand against?
questions.explanation: Job 15:25 says the wicked man stretcheth out his hand against God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Job 15:31: 'Let not him that is deceived trust in ______: for vanity shall be his recompence.'
questions.explanation: Job 15:31 says, 'Let not him that is deceived trust in vanity.'

questions.question: What will happen to the congregation of hypocrites according to Job 15:34?
options: They shall be desolate and consumed by fire
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be desolate and consumed by fire
questions.explanation: Job 15:34 states the congregation of hypocrites shall be desolate and fire shall consume their tabernacles.

questions.question: True or False: Job 15:13 accuses Job of turning his spirit against God.
questions.explanation: Job 15:13 accuses Job of turning his spirit against God and letting such words go out of his mouth.

questions.question: According to Job 15:35, what do the hypocrites conceive and bring forth?
questions.explanation: Job 15:35 says they conceive mischief and bring forth vanity, and their belly prepareth deceit.

medium.title: Job Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of self-righteousness and pride. Based on Job 15, what biblical truth would you share about human righteousness?
options: Man born of a woman should be righteous
Man is clean and without sin
What is man, that he should be clean?
Humans can be perfectly clean before God
questions.correctAnswer: What is man, that he should be clean?
questions.explanation: Job 15:14 teaches that man, born of a woman, is not inherently righteous or clean. This reminds us to practice humility and trust in God's grace rather than self-righteousness.

questions.question: How does Job 15 teach us about the importance of prayer and reverence towards God when facing trials?
options: You should restrain prayer before God
Fear and prayer should not be cast off
Only the wise can pray effectively
questions.correctAnswer: Fear and prayer should not be cast off
questions.explanation: In Job 15:4, Eliphaz rebukes Job for casting off fear and restraining prayer before God, emphasizing the need to maintain reverence and communication with God during hardships.

questions.question: What warning does Job 15 give about trusting in vanity or deceptive things during difficult times?
questions.explanation: Job 15:31 warns that those deceived who trust in vanity will receive vanity as their reward, encouraging believers to place trust in God rather than worthless things.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the apparent prosperity of the wicked. According to Job 15, what truth can you share about the end of the wicked?
options: The wicked will return to darkness
The wicked have secure, long lives
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked will return to darkness
questions.explanation: Job 15:22 says the wicked do not believe they will return out of darkness, but they are awaited by the sword, showing that their prosperity is temporary and judgment is sure.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach about the consequences of turning one’s spirit against God?
options: It leads to destruction and desolation
It results in wealth and honor
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to destruction and desolation
questions.explanation: Job 15:13 and 15:28 describe how turning one's spirit against God results in desolate cities and houses ready to become heaps, symbolizing ruin and loss.

questions.question: What does Job 15 say about the knowledge and wisdom of the elders compared to younger men?
options: The very aged men are much elder than thy father
questions.correctAnswer: The very aged men are much elder than thy father
questions.explanation: Job 15:10 highlights that the company of elders is greater and their wisdom more established than that of younger men, encouraging respect for mature wisdom.

questions.question: How does Job 15 instruct us about honesty and integrity in speech?
options: Choosing the tongue of the crafty is commendable
Your own mouth and lips can condemn you
Speech does not affect spiritual life
Unprofitable talk is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Your own mouth and lips can condemn you
questions.explanation: Job 15:5-6 explains that iniquity can be uttered by the mouth and that one’s own lips testify against oneself, teaching the importance of truthful and godly speech.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 15, the heavens are clean in God's sight and He puts trust in His saints.
questions.explanation: Job 15:15 states that God puts no trust in His saints and even the heavens are not clean in His sight, emphasizing God's absolute holiness and humanity's imperfection.

questions.question: How does Job 15 encourage believers to respond to temptation and trials related to pride and self-sufficiency?
options: Stretch out your hand against God
Do not run upon God but trust in Him
questions.correctAnswer: Do not run upon God but trust in Him
questions.explanation: Job 15:25-26 describes the folly of opposing God, urging believers to rely on Him rather than pridefully confronting Him.

questions.question: What does Job 15 say about the fate of those who conceive mischief and bring forth vanity?
options: Their belly prepares deceit and fire consumes their tabernacles
They will be honored among the people
questions.correctAnswer: Their belly prepares deceit and fire consumes their tabernacles
questions.explanation: Job 15:34-35 explain that hypocrites conceive mischief and their deeds lead to destruction by fire, warning against deceit and corruption.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The wicked man travaileth with pain all his days, and the number of years is hidden to the _______."
questions.explanation: Job 15:20 states that the wicked man suffers pain and the number of his years is hidden to the oppressor, highlighting the secret and difficult life of the wicked.

questions.question: What practical lesson about contentment and humility can we learn from the question, "Art thou the first man that was born? or wast thou made before the hills?" in Job 15?
options: We should consider ourselves as the oldest
We should not presume to have greater wisdom than God or creation
We are the masters of the world
We are born before the hills
questions.correctAnswer: We should not presume to have greater wisdom than God or creation
questions.explanation: Job 15:7 challenges pride by asking if one was first born or created before the hills, teaching humility and respect for God's sovereign wisdom.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 15, the wicked man will not depart out of darkness and his branch shall not be green.
questions.explanation: Job 15:30-32 describe how the wicked will remain in darkness, and their branch will not thrive, illustrating the consequences of wickedness in spiritual and practical terms.

questions.question: According to Job 15, what is the result of a man who 'drinketh iniquity like water'?
options: He lives a long and peaceful life
questions.explanation: Job 15:16 calls such a man abominable and filthy, warning against habitual sin and its defiling effects on the believer’s life.

questions.question: What does Job 15 teach about relying on the wisdom passed down by previous generations?
options: Wise men have declared it openly from their fathers
No one can understand ancient wisdom
It is irrelevant to current trials
questions.correctAnswer: Wise men have declared it openly from their fathers
questions.explanation: Job 15:17-18 explains that wise men have openly shared what they have seen and learned from their ancestors, encouraging believers to learn from godly tradition.

hard.title: Job Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 15.

questions.question: In Job 15, Eliphaz accuses Job of filling his belly with what?
questions.explanation: Eliphaz says, 'Should a wise man utter vain knowledge, and fill his belly with the east wind?' (Job 15:2), symbolizing emptiness and futility.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say is chosen by Job's tongue according to Job 15?
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states, 'thou choosest the tongue of the crafty,' highlighting Eliphaz's accusation of deceitfulness.

questions.question: Eliphaz questions Job's claim to special knowledge by asking if Job was made before what?
questions.explanation: In Job 15:7, Eliphaz rhetorically asks, 'Art thou the first man that was born? or wast thou made before the hills?' to challenge Job's presumed wisdom.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz in Job 15, what is the state of the heavens in God's sight?
questions.explanation: Job 15:15 states, 'the heavens are not clean in his sight,' indicating God's high standard of holiness even for the heavens.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'How much more abominable and filthy is man, which drinketh ______ like water?'
questions.explanation: Job 15:16 uses the metaphor 'which drinketh iniquity like water' to emphasize human sinfulness.

questions.question: What type of men does Eliphaz say have passed down the wisdom he is about to declare?
questions.explanation: Job 15:18 states that wise men have told these things from their fathers, indicating oral tradition.

questions.question: According to Job 15, who alone was the earth given to, among whom no stranger passed?
questions.explanation: Verse 19 says, 'Unto whom alone the earth was given, and no stranger passed among them,' referring to the lineage of wise men.

questions.question: What is the fate of the wicked man as described in Job 15?
options: He travaileth with pain all his days and is waited for by the sword
questions.correctAnswer: He travaileth with pain all his days and is waited for by the sword
questions.explanation: Job 15:20-22 describe the wicked man's life as full of suffering and impending destruction.

questions.question: Eliphaz uses the imagery of a king ready to battle to describe what feeling experienced by the wicked?
options: Trouble and anguish prevailing against him
questions.correctAnswer: Trouble and anguish prevailing against him
questions.explanation: Verse 24 compares trouble and anguish overcoming the wicked to a king ready for battle.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 15, the wicked man trusts that he will return out of darkness.
questions.explanation: Job 15:22 states, 'He believeth not that he shall return out of darkness,' showing the hopelessness of the wicked.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say the wicked man stretches out his hand against?
questions.explanation: Verse 25 says, 'For he stretcheth out his hand against God,' portraying the wicked man's rebellion.

questions.question: How does Eliphaz describe the wicked man's dwelling places in Job 15?
options: Desolate cities and houses which no man inhabiteth
questions.correctAnswer: Desolate cities and houses which no man inhabiteth
questions.explanation: Job 15:28 describes the wicked as dwelling in abandoned places, symbolizing desolation.

questions.question: According to Job 15, what will happen to the wicked man's substance and riches?
options: He shall not be rich, nor shall his substance continue
He shall gain great wealth and prosper
He will leave a great inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not be rich, nor shall his substance continue
questions.explanation: Verse 29 states clearly that the wicked man's wealth will not last.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Let not him that is _______ trust in vanity: for vanity shall be his recompence.'
questions.explanation: Job 15:31 warns the deceived not to trust in vanity, emphasizing futility.

questions.question: What imagery does Eliphaz use in Job 15 to describe the premature end of the wicked man's prosperity?
options: He shall shake off his unripe grape and cast off his flower as the olive
He shall build barns and gather plentifully
He shall bloom like the lily and flourish
He shall shine like the stars forever
questions.correctAnswer: He shall shake off his unripe grape and cast off his flower as the olive
questions.explanation: Verse 33 uses agricultural imagery to show the sudden loss of the wicked's potential and fruitfulness.

theological.title: Job Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz in Job 15, what does a wise man not do?
options: Utter vain knowledge and fill his belly with the east wind
Speak words of comfort to the afflicted
Pray continually and trust in God
questions.correctAnswer: Utter vain knowledge and fill his belly with the east wind
questions.explanation: Job 15:2 states that a wise man should not utter vain knowledge or fill his belly with the east wind, indicating that true wisdom rejects empty, unprofitable speech. This aligns with Proverbs 10:14 which praises wise men for storing knowledge, and James 1:5 which encourages seeking true wisdom from God.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz accuse Job of casting off, according to Job 15?
options: Hope and faith in God's promises
questions.explanation: Job 15:4 accuses Job of casting off fear and restraining prayer before God, which implies a turning away from reverence and reliance on God. This reflects the biblical principle seen in Psalm 111:10, where the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and 1 Thessalonians 5:17 which commands to pray without ceasing.

questions.question: In Job 15, Eliphaz challenges Job by asking if he was made before what?
questions.explanation: Job 15:7 questions Job if he was made before the hills, emphasizing the created order and God's sovereignty. This recalls Psalm 90:2 where God is eternal, existing before the mountains were formed, highlighting human limitation compared to divine eternity.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say about man's righteousness in Job 15?
options: Man cannot be clean or righteous
Man is inherently righteous before God
Man’s righteousness is fully accepted by God
questions.correctAnswer: Man cannot be clean or righteous
questions.explanation: Job 15:14 declares that man cannot be clean or righteous, reflecting the doctrine of original sin and human depravity seen in Genesis 6:5, Psalm 51:5, and Romans 3:10-12 which teach that all have sinned and fall short of God's glory.

questions.question: How does Eliphaz describe man’s relationship with iniquity in Job 15?
options: Man is free from iniquity by nature
Man occasionally sins but is mostly righteous
Man’s iniquity is negligible before God
questions.explanation: Job 15:16 states that man drinks iniquity like water, emphasizing the pervasive nature of sin in humanity. This is consistent with Isaiah 59:7-8 which describes sin as deeply embedded, and Romans 5:12 which explains sin entered the world through one man.

questions.question: According to Job 15, what is hidden to the oppressor?
options: The number of years he will live
questions.correctAnswer: The number of years he will live
questions.explanation: Job 15:20 says the number of years is hidden to the oppressor, indicating that the duration of the wicked’s suffering or life is unknown and under God’s sovereign control. Psalm 37:10-11 and Proverbs 10:27 similarly teach that God’s judgment is certain though timing is hidden.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say will come upon the wicked in prosperity, according to Job 15?
questions.explanation: Job 15:21 warns that in prosperity, the destroyer shall come upon the wicked, highlighting the eschatological judgment of God. This is consistent with Proverbs 11:31 and Revelation 20:12-15 which teach that prosperity does not exempt one from divine judgment.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say about the wicked man's hope of returning from darkness in Job 15?
options: He believes not that he shall return out of darkness
He is assured of salvation through repentance
He confidently expects a new beginning
He trusts in God's mercy for restoration
questions.correctAnswer: He believes not that he shall return out of darkness
questions.explanation: Job 15:22 describes the wicked as not believing they will return from darkness, indicating despair and judgment. This corresponds with Psalm 49:14 and Hebrews 10:26-27, which warn against hardening one’s heart and rejecting salvation.

questions.question: According to Job 15, what will trouble and anguish do to the wicked?
options: Make him afraid and prevail against him
Cause him to repent and be restored
Lead him to comfort and peace
questions.correctAnswer: Make him afraid and prevail against him
questions.explanation: Job 15:24 declares that trouble and anguish will make the wicked afraid and prevail against him, showing the consequences of sin and divine discipline. This aligns with Isaiah 33:14 and Hebrews 12:5-11 which teach that the fear of the Lord brings correction.

questions.question: In Job 15, what does Eliphaz say the wicked man does in relation to God?
options: He stretches out his hand and strengthens himself against the Almighty
He humbles himself and seeks God's mercy
He praises God in the assembly of the saints
He trusts in God's covenant promises
questions.correctAnswer: He stretches out his hand and strengthens himself against the Almighty
questions.explanation: Job 15:25 explains that the wicked man stretches out his hand against God and strengthens himself against the Almighty, illustrating rebellion against divine authority. This is comparable to Psalm 2:1-4 and Isaiah 14:13-14 which describe the arrogance and rebellion of the wicked.

questions.question: How does Eliphaz describe the dwelling place of the wicked in Job 15?
options: Desolate cities and houses ready to become heaps
questions.correctAnswer: Desolate cities and houses ready to become heaps
questions.explanation: Job 15:28 states the wicked dwells in desolate cities and houses which no man inhabit, symbolizing ruin and judgment. This imagery parallels Isaiah 1:7 and Jeremiah 9:11 where the desolation of the wicked’s dwellings is a sign of God’s judgment.

questions.question: What will not continue for the wicked according to Job 15?
options: His substance and perfection upon the earth
questions.correctAnswer: His substance and perfection upon the earth
questions.explanation: Job 15:29 says the wicked shall not be rich nor prolong the perfection of his substance upon the earth, indicating the futility of worldly gains apart from God. This corresponds to Proverbs 10:3 and 1 Timothy 6:9 which warn against trusting in fleeting riches.

questions.question: According to Job 15, how will the wicked depart from the earth?
options: He shall depart out of darkness by the breath of his mouth
He shall be welcomed into the kingdom of heaven
He shall live long and prosper
He shall be restored and forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: He shall depart out of darkness by the breath of his mouth
questions.explanation: Job 15:30 describes the wicked departing out of darkness by the breath of his mouth, which figuratively indicates death and destruction. This aligns with Psalm 18:42 and James 4:14 which remind us of the brevity of life and the certainty of death.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz warn about trusting in vanity in Job 15?
options: The deceived will receive vanity as their recompense
Trusting vanity brings peace and joy
Vanity is the foundation of true wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: The deceived will receive vanity as their recompense
questions.explanation: Job 15:31 warns that those deceived by vanity will have vanity as their recompense, teaching the futility of trusting in worthless things. This is consistent with Ecclesiastes 1:2 and Matthew 6:19-21 which admonish believers to seek eternal treasures, not vain ones.

questions.question: What will happen to the branch of the wicked before its time, according to Job 15?
options: It shall flourish and bear fruit
It shall be blessed by God
It shall be planted in the house of the Lord
questions.explanation: Job 15:32 states the wicked’s branch shall not be green before its time, symbolizing premature destruction. This matches Psalm 37:35-36 and Jeremiah 17:8 which contrast the fate of the wicked with the flourishing of the righteous.
